The bottom line: this bill is a responsible solution that will reduce drug prices for thousands of Washingtonians improve Medicare coverage and make smart investments to improve the health of all Americans. I'm proud we passed  #HR3 out of the House today. (14/14)

Lastly the bill uses these savings to invest in biomedical research to find cures for the most devastating diseases. And it makes investments to respond to some of our most urgent health issues: health worker shortage maternal mortality crisis and opioid epidemic. #HR3 (13/14) https://t.co/l8YsFFxv7x

The savings from lower Medicare drug spending are so large that #HR3 also expands Medicare to cover dental vision and hearing care for all beneficiaries. These are critical elements of total health care and including them in Medicare is a great achievement. (12/14) https://t.co/bj73IXNcuF

For Medicare the savings are plowed back into improved benefits for seniors. For Medicare beneficiaries the bill creates a limit on out-of-pocket spending and adds new subsidies for low-income seniors. #HR3 (11/14) https://t.co/Fg4e8Ai1xb

These lower prices will be available to both Medicare beneficiaries and individuals with private insurance. This will translate into lower premiums and lower cost sharing for people with private insurance. #HR3 (10/14)

The bill also imposes financial penalties on drug companies that dramatically hike their prices. To give context the average annual cost of prescription drugs rose nearly 58% between 2012 and 2017. That number should concern all of us. #HR3 (9/14)

Now onto the details:   This bill requires HHS to negotiate prices for 50-250 drugs per year (drugmakers will face stiff financial penalties if they refuse to negotiate). Budget experts say the lower prices will reduce fed spending by $456 billion over the 2020s. #HR3 (8/14)

For years my colleagues—including my friend the late Elijah Cummings—worked to make drug price negotiation a reality. Many of these ideas inspired the bill we passed today #HR3 which is why it is formally named the Elijah E. Cummings Lower Drug Costs Now Act (7/14)

Medicare which provides health coverage to 60 million Americans lacks the power to negotiate drug prices. Almost $1 of every $5 spent in Medicare now goes to prescription drugs and the total cost over the next decade will be in the trillions of dollars. #HR3 (6/14)

Parts of our government already negotiate drug prices. The VA is allowed to negotiate prices for the drugs it buys for veterans and drug companies are required to provide price discounts to Medicaid. As a result the VA and Medicaid pay much lower drug prices. #HR3 (5/14)

These problems don’t happen in other countries. The reason prescription drugs are cheaper abroad than in the U.S. is because those governments take a more active role in negotiating lower prices. #HR3 (4/14) https://t.co/YwlOZdxMLv

I also hear from constituents who work in the health care industry and see firsthand the impacts of our broken prescription drug market. I received this letter last month from Gordon from Tumwater and found it particularly moving #HR3 (3/14) https://t.co/uRINbmC3h2
